q: Despite cuts, however, the Michael Government was now keen to bring about much-needed improvements.`` Some of the school buildings in Northumberland are old and in need of upgrading,'' he said. There has been a bit of investment, but that's generally been in the south-east of the county.`` At the moment, we are reviewing how we spend money on school buildings and among the key criteria will be the condition of those buildings. Mr Michael Gove added he was hopeful progress could be made.`` The headteachers are not asking for unrealistic sums and appreciate these are difficult economic times.`` I was able to explain why the

.'' Gbagbo's camp has dismissed Alassane Ouattara 's export ban as unenforceable. Spokesman Ahoua Don Mello says the reality is that cocoa shipments continue.`` Every day cocoa is being shipped out,'' he says. Trying to cripple Ivory Coast economically is not possible. Cocoa exports will continue. Coffee too and rubber because it's the foreigners themselves who need them. An estimated seven million people live off cocoa in Ivory Coast. Francophone West Africa's economic powerhouse has been in political limbo since November's election. The vote was supposed to end almost a

as regional leaders mulled military intervention to break the deadlock. Mr Gbagbo had accepted an offer of talks with his rival made on Monday by African Union mediator in the weeks-long crisis. There was an offer of dialogue between the two camps. It was accepted... a meeting depends on the response of the Alassane Ouattara camp, Ahoua Don Mello said. Mr Alassane Ouattara 's team would not immediately comment. Mr Gbagbo has said before that he is willing to talk with his rival over the dispute but he has refused all offers to

American politics could use a Simon Cowell , but would he ever get elected to anything?

Mr Michael Gove insisted that under-achieving academies will not be exempt from this.
